body.p: CHAPTER 40 MIDNIGHT, FORECASTLE.

HARPOONEERS AND SAILORS. (Foresail(Foresail rises . . . all singing in chorus.): In Melville’s forecastle drama, the rising sail is a curtain that “discovers” (reveals) the on-duty crewmen. rises and discovers the watch standing, lounging, leaning, and lying in various attitudes, all singing in chorus.)

FarewellFarewell and adieu to you, Spanish ladies!: From the popular nautical song, “Spanish Ladies.” Most versions read, “For we’ve received orders” to sail homeward, rather than Melville’s “Our captain’s commanded—”. See also Making Moby-Dick. and adieu to you, Spanish ladies! Farewell and adieu to you, ladies of Spain! Our captain’s commanded—
1ST NANTUCKET SAILOR. Oh, boys, don’t be sentimental; it’s bad for the digestion! Take a tonic, follow me! (Sings, and all follow.)

Our captainOur captain stood upon the deck . . . : Melville found this sailor song in J. Ross Browne, Etchings of a Whaling Cruise: With Notes of a Sojourn on the Island of Zanzibar, To Which is Appended a Brief History of the Whale Fishery, Its Past and Present Condition , where it is called “Captain Bunker.” See Stuart M. Frank, "King of the Southern Sea." stood upon the deck, A spy-glass in his hand, A viewing of those gallant whales That blew at every strandstrand: wave.. Oh, your tubs in your boats, my boys, And by your braces stand, And we’ll have one of those fine whales, Hand, boys, over hand! So, be cheery, my lads! may your hearts never fail! While the bold harpooneer is striking the whale!
MATE’S VOICE FROM THE QUARTER-DECK. Eight bellsEight bells: midnight. there, forward!

2D NANTUCKET SAILOR. Avast the chorus! Eight bells there! d’ye hear, bell-boy? Strike the bell eight, thou Pip! thou blackling! and let me call the watch. I’ve the sort of mouth for that—the hogsheadhogshead: Large cask. A "barrel" in the 19th century was a unit of measurement equal to 31-1/2 gallons of whale oil; a "hogshead" equaled two barrels or 63 gallons of whale oil. mouth. So, so, (thrusts his head down the scuttle,) StarStar—bo-l-e-e-n-s, a-h-o-y! : The men in the starboard watch (“starbowlines” or “starboleens” in sailor speech) are being called to the deck from their off-duty sleep to relieve the larboard (port) watch, but they are slow to appear. In the following speeches, the Dutch sailor compares their reluctance to leave their beds to the difficulty of hauling up the lowest level of oil barrels in the hold, and he facetiously advises using the copper pump (meant for pumping whale oil from one barrel to another) as a megaphone. As their shipmates appear from below, the French sailor calls for a dance before he and his mates in the larboard watch go to sleep.—bo-l-e-e-n-s, a-h-o-y! Eight bells there below! Tumble up!

DUTCH SAILOR. Grand snoozing to-night, maty; fat night for that. I mark this in our old Mogul’s wine; it’s quite as deadening to some as fillipingfilliping: stimulating. to others. We sing; they sleep—aye, lie down there, like ground-tier butts. At ’em again! There, take this copper-pump, and hail ’em through it. Tell ’em to avast dreaming of their lasses. Tell ’em it’s the resurrection; they must kiss their last, and come to judgment. That’s the way—that’s it; thy throat ain’t spoiled with eating Amsterdam butterAmsterdam butter: The joke is that the common sailors were not fed butter, with its supposedly voice-smoothing properties, much less highly-esteemed and expensive Dutch butter; see Bildad’s concern over the price of butter, and Flask’s avoidance of it (Chs. 21, 35). See Amsterdam, Netherlands..

FRENCH SAILOR. Hist, boys! let’s have a jig or two before we ride to anchor in Blanket Bay. What say ye? There comes the other watch. Stand by all legs! Pip! little Pip! hurrah with your tambourineThe tambourine was one of the instruments that was often included in the foo-foo, or impromptu musical, band found on19th-century sailing vessels and made up of members of the ship's crew. The tambourine is also associated with minstrel bands, in which white--and occasionally black--musicians blacked their faces and played music of African Americans. For an image of the tambourine, see the cover of the Virginia Minstrels.!
PIP. (Sulky and sleepy.) Don’t know where it is.

FRENCH SAILOR. Beat thy belly, then, and wag thy ears. Jig it, men, I say; merry’s the word; hurrah! Damn me, won’t you dance? Form, now, Indian-file, and gallop into the double-shuffledouble-shuffle: Dickens, Charles, 1812-1870 called it “a low, noisy dance.”? Throw yourselves! Legs! legs!
ICELAND SAILOR. I don’t like your floor, maty; it’s too springy to my taste. I’m used to ice-floors. I’m sorry to throw cold water on the subject; but excuse me.
MALTESE SAILOR. Me too; where’s your girls? Who but a fool would take his left hand by his right, and say to himself, how d’ye do? Partners! I must have partners!
SICILIAN SAILOR. Aye; girls and a greengreen: village commons, or grassy lawn.!—then I’ll hop with ye; yea, turn grasshopper!

LONG-ISLAND SAILOR. Well, well, ye sulkies, there’s plenty more of us. Hoe cornHoe corn: do a hoe-down, a wild country dance. when you may, say I. All legs go to harvest soon. Ah! here comes the music; now for it!

AZORE SAILOR. (Ascending, and pitching the tambourine up the scuttle.) Here you are, Pip; and there’s the windlass-bittswindlass-bitts: two strong vertical timbers supporting the ends of the windlass.; up you mount! Now, boys! (The half of them dance to the tambourine; some go below; some sleep or lie among the coils of rigging. Oaths a-plenty.)
AZORE SAILOR. (Dancing.) Go it, Pip! Bang it, bell-boy! Rig it, dig it, stig it, quig it, bell-boy! Make fire-flies; break the jinglers!
PIP. Jinglers, you say?—there goes another, dropped off; I pound it so.
CHINA SAILOR. Rattle thy teeth, then, and pound away; make a pagodamake a pagoda of thyself: bells were often hung on Chinese pagodas. of thyself.
FRENCH SAILOR. Merry-mad! Hold up thy hoop, Pip, till I jump through it! Split jibs!Split jibs!: split yourselves like sails torn in a violent storm. tear yourselves!
TASHTEGO. (Quietly smoking.) That’s a white man; he calls that fun: humph! I save my sweat.

OLD MANX SAILOR. I wonder whether those jolly lads bethink them of what they are dancing over. I’ll dance over your grave, I will—that’s the bitterest threat of your night-womennight-women . . . beat: either witches, who can supposedly make such maneuvers in the air, or, perhaps, prostitutes. To beat means to sail close to the wind. In order to beat around a corner, a vessel must tack one way and then the other; the vessel cannot simply go straight. Head-winds are winds that come from ahead and thus force a vessel to tack back and forth., that beat head-winds round corners. O Christ! to think of the green navies and the green-skulled crews! Well, well; belikebelike the whole world’s a ball, as you scholars have it: An echo of “All the world’s a stage,” from Shakespeare’s As You Like It, in The Dramatic Works of William Shakespeare, 2.7. The Manx sailor’s pun transforms the scholars’ view that the world is probably (“belike”) a globe into the sailor view that it is a ballroom, and a place for sexual encounter as well. See also Making Moby-Dick. the whole world’s a ball, as you scholars have it; and so ’tis right to make one ball-room of it. Dance on, lads, you’re young; I was once.
3D NANTUCKET SAILOR. Spell oh!—whew! this is worse than pulling after whales in a calm—give us a whiff, Tash.
(They cease dancing, and gather in clusters. Meantime the sky darkens—the wind rises.)

LASCARLascar: from Lashkar, India; here, an Indian sailor. SAILOR. By BrahmaBrahma and Seeva are the Hindu gods of creation and destruction, respectively; the Ganges is India’s holy river.! boys, it’ll be douse sail soon. The sky-born, high-tide Ganges turned to wind! Thou showest thy black brow, Seeva!

MALTESE SAILOR. (Reclining and shaking his cap.) It’s the waves—the snow’s caps turn to jig it now. They’ll shake their tassels soon. Now would all the waves were women, then I’d go drown, and chasseechassee: dance. with them evermore! There’s naught so sweet on earth—heaven may not match it!—as those swift glances of warm, wild bosoms in the dance, when the over-arboring arms hide such ripe, bursting grapes.

SICILIAN SAILOR. (Reclining.) Tell me not of it! Hark ye, lad—fleet interlacings of the limbs—lithe swayings—coyings—flutterings! lip! heart! hip! all graze: unceasing touch and go! not taste, observe ye, else come satiety. Eh, Pagan? (Nudging.)

TAHITIAN SAILOR. (Reclining on a mat.) Hail, holy nakedness of our dancing girls!—the Heeva-HeevaHeeva-Heeva: Tahitian dance of peace.! Ah! low veiled, high palmed Tahiti!Tahiti!: Now part of French Polynesia and a major tourist destination, in the early nineteenth century Tahiti was virtually synonymous with Paradise. Refusing to work on the Australian whaleship Lucy Ann, in 1842, Melville and several mates were imprisoned on Tahiti for a month. He and a companion escaped to its neighboring island, Eimeo (Moorea). Omoo is based on those adventures. See also Making Moby-Dick. I still rest me on thy mat, but the soft soil has slid! I saw thee woven in the wood, my mat! green the first day I brought ye thence; now worn and wilted quite. Ah me!—not thou nor I can bear the change! How then, if so be transplanted to yon sky? Hear I the roaring streams from PirohiteePirohitee’s peak of spears: Melville apparently made up this jagged mountain’s name, also used in Omoo.’s peak of spears, when they leap down the crags and drown the villages?—The blast! the blast! Up, spine, and meet it! (Leaps to his feet.)
PORTUGUESE SAILOR. How the sea rolls swashing ’gainst the side! Stand by for reefing, hearties! the winds are just crossing swords, pell-mell they’ll go lunging presently.

DANISH SAILOR. CrackCrack, crack, old ship!: Wooden ships make such noises adjusting themselves to the sea and wind; a noisy ship was said to be a safe one. Also an echo of words uttered during a storm in King Lear, in The Dramatic Works of William Shakespeare, 3.2.1, “Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! rage! blow!”, crack, old ship! so long as thou crackest, thou holdest! Well done! The mate there holds ye to it stiffly. He’s no more afraid than the isle fort at Cattegatthe isle fort at Cattegat: The Kattegat is the part of the North Sea between Denmark and Sweden. No island fort there has been identified. See Kattegat Strait, put there to fight the Baltic with storm-lashed guns, on which the sea-salt cakes!

4TH NANTUCKET SAILOR. He has his orders, mind ye that. I heard old Ahab tell him he must always kill a squall, something as they burst a water-spoutwater-spout: A waterspout is an intense columnar vortex (usually appearing as a funnel-shaped cloud) that occurs over a body of water. Early sailors believed that a water-spout could be broken apart by shooting guns at it. See canto II of William Falconer's The Shipwreck. with a pistol—fire your ship right into it!
ENGLISH SAILOR. Blood! but that old man’s a grand old covecove: fellow.! We are the lads to hunt him up his whale!
ALL. Aye! aye!

OLD MANX SAILOR. How the three pinespines: ship’s masts. Ship's masts were often built of pine; later, once it became easier to ship goods from the West coast of the United States to the East coast, douglas fir became the preferred wood for ship's masts. shake! Pines are the hardest sort of
tree to live when shifted to any other soil, and here there’s none but the crew’s cursed clay. Steady, helmsman! steady. This is the sort of weather when brave hearts snap ashore, and keeled hulls split at sea. Our captain has his birth-mark; look yonder, boys, there’s another in the sky—lurid-like, ye see, all else pitch black.
DAGGOO. What of that? Who’s afraid of black’s afraid of me! I’m quarried out of it!

SPANISH SAILOR. (Aside.) He wants to bully, ah!—the old grudgethe old grudge: Racial antipathy, exacerbated in this case by Daggoo’s legitimate grudge against whites for enslaving black Africans while associating them with the devil, as the Spaniard says. Perhaps, too, the Spanish sailor is “touchy” because his nation was a leader in that slave trade. makes me touchy. (Advancing.) Aye, harpooneer, thy race is the undeniable dark side of mankind—devilish dark at that. No offence.
DAGGOO (grimly). None.

ST. JAGO’S SAILORST. JAGO’S SAILOR: St. Jago is a corruption of Sao Tiago (Santiago) , Cape Verde, in the Cape Verde Islands off the west coast of Africa.. That Spaniard’s mad or drunk. But that can’t be, or else in his one case our old Mogul’s fire-waters are somewhat long in working.
5TH NANTUCKET SAILOR. What’s that I saw—lightning? Yes.
SPANISH SAILOR. No; Daggoo showing his teeth.
DAGGOO (springing). Swallow thine, mannikinmannikin: little one. Literally, a person who is very small, especially one not otherwise abnormal or deformed.! White skin, white liver!
SPANISH SAILOR (meeting him). Knife thee heartily! big frame, small spirit!
ALL. A row! a row! a row!
TASHTEGO (with a whiff). A row a’low, and a row aloft—Gods and men—both brawlers! Humph!
BELFAST SAILOR. A row! arraharrah: Anglo-Irish, really. a row! The Virgin be blessed, a row! Plunge in with ye!
ENGLISH SAILOR. Fair play! Snatch the Spaniard’s knife! A ring, a ring!
OLD MANX SAILOR. Ready formed. There! the ringed horizon. In that ring Cain struck Abel. Sweet work, right work! No? Why then, God, mad’st thou the ring?

MATE’S VOICE FROM THE QUARTER DECK. HandsHands by the halyards! in top-gallant sails! Stand by to reef topsails!: The mate orders the men to reduce the ship’s sail area, first by mustering them to lower the sails with the halyards, then by ordering them aloft to furl the top-gallant sails, which are the sails that are set above the topsails, and finally to reef, or reduce the size of, the topsails. The topsails are usually the first sails set and the last taken down; the fact that they have to be reefed indicates that the storm is quite strong. by the halyards! in top-gallant sails! Stand by to reef topsails!
ALL. The squall! the squall! jump, my jollies! (They scatter.)

PIP (shrinking under the windlass). Jollies? Lord help such jollies! Crish, crash! there goes the jib-stayjib-stay . . . royal yard!: According to Pip, the stay leading from the top of the foremast to the jib-boom (on which the triangular jib is strung) has snapped, and the royal yard, four levels above the deck, is crashing down; if true, these would amount to a serious accident. In the absence of other evidence of damage, though, it seems that Pip’s fear is already running away with him, long before his disastrous leap in Ch. 93. The jib-stay is an essential part of the standing rigging that keeps the masts upright.! Blang-whang! God! Duck lower, Pip, here comes the royalroyal yard: The royal is the highest sail on the mast, above the foresail, fore topsail, and fore togallant sail. The yard is the wooden crosspiece from which the royal sail hangs. yard! It’s worse than being in the whirled woods, the last day of the year! Who’d go climbing after chestnuts now? But there they go, all cursing, and here I don’t. Fine prospects to ’em; they’re on the roadroad to heaven: to reach the sails, the sailors are climbing the rigging. to heaven. Hold on hard! Jimmini, what a squall! But those chaps there are worse yet—they are your white squallswhite squalls: A white squall is a sudden and violent windstorm at sea that is not accompanied by the black clouds generally characteristic of a squall. Because the sailors cannot see a white squall approaching, it is feared far more than a regular squall., they. White squalls? white whale, shirr! shirr! Here have I heard all their chat just now, and the white whale—shirr! shirr!—but spoken of once! and only this evening—it makes me jingle all over like my tambourine—that anaconda of an old man swore ’em in to hunt him! Oh, thou big white God aloft there somewhere in yon darkness, have mercy on this small black boy down here; preserve him from all men that have no bowelsbowels: in scripture, the seat of pity or kindness; the supposed bodily source of compassion. to feel fear! * * * * * *
